nodes.text: Conditional convergence hypothesis: controlling for initial human capital, lower initial real per capita GDP predicts faster subsequent per capita GDP growth across countries (1960-1985); initial human capital positively predicts subsequent growth

Method: cross-sectional econometric analysis of 98 countries using average annual growth of real per capita GDP 1960-1985 and regressions with White heteroskedasticity-consistent standard errors; robustness checks include alternative weighting, alternate dependent periods, and instrumenting

Result: In multivariate regressions (with school-enrollment controls), the estimated coefficient on 1960 per capita GDP is negative and significant (example: -0.0075 per $1000, s.e. 0.0012), implying higher initial GDP lowers subsequent growth when human capital held constant

Result: Initial human capital proxies (1960 secondary and primary school-enrollment rates SEC60 and PRIM60) have positive and significant coefficients for subsequent per capita GDP growth; joint F test strongly rejects zero

Evidence: Partial correlations and figures show strong negative partial association between growth and GDP60 (partial correlation -0.74) and strong positive partial association between growth and combined school-enrollment index (partial correlation 0.73)
Claim: Higher initial human capital is associated with lower fertility and higher physical investment, consistent with endogenous-growth and fertility models

Result/Evidence: Fertility regressions show net fertility (FERTNET) is strongly negatively related to school-enrollment measures while GDP60 is insignificant, and investment regressions show private and total investment ratios positively related to school-enrollment and negatively to GDP60

Claim: Government consumption share of GDP (gc/y) is negatively associated with subsequent growth and with private investment, while public investment shows little robust positive relation to growth once total investment is controlled

Result/Evidence: Regression estimates show gc/y coefficient negative and significant for growth (example: -0.12, s.e. 0.03) and negative for private investment; public investment coefficients are small and statistically insignificant when total investment is included
Claim: Political instability indicators (revolutions/coups REV and assassinations ASSASS) are negatively associated with investment and growth, interpreted as adverse effects on property rights

Evidence/Result: REV and ASSASS have statistically significant negative coefficients in growth and investment regressions; correlations of residuals are consistent with endogenous-growth model predictions (residual correlation positive between growth and investment, negative between growth and fertility)
Claim: Price distortions proxied by deviations of purchasing-power-parity for the investment deflator (PPPIGO deviation) are negatively related to growth and to investment ratios

Evidence/Result: The magnitude of PPP investment-deflator deviation (PPIGODEV) enters negatively and significantly in growth regressions (example coefficient -0.014, s.e. 0.005), while the algebraic PPPIGO level is insignificantly related

Result/Conclusion: Continent dummies for sub-Saharan Africa and Latin America remain significantly negative for growth even after controlling for human capital, investment ratios, fertility, government spending, instability, and price-distortion proxies, indicating unexplained adverse effects in these regions

Limitation: Measurement and proxy issues include imperfect proxies for human capital (enrollment rates vs stock), data quality concerns for 1950 schooling and literacy measures, possible persistent measurement error in GDP, and remaining omitted factors especially for Africa and Latin America

Conclusion: Empirical evidence supports that initial human capital raises subsequent growth and that, conditional on human capital, poorer countries tend to grow faster; government consumption, political instability, and price distortions are adverse for growth, but much of regional poor performance remains unexplained
